page.title: 09KETTLEWELL - DAIRY FARMING
page.content: Dairy farming is an important part of agriculture though most dairy herds are now kept to the lower end of the valley. They are fairly small and consist of Friesian cows. The milk is taken by tanker to the Milk Marketing Board depots but some of it is sold retail around the villages. Cows are grazed in the valley bottoms, but dry cows and younger animals are often summered on the hills. Hay is the main winter fodder but silage is also made and fed, with concentrates, throughout the year to lactating cows. Calves are bred and reared to both supplement the dairy herd and to sell for store cattle. There are also several small suckler herds in the area, chiefly Hereford and Charolais breeds. Grass is the only crop and it is grown for hay and silage for sheep and cattle. Pigs are not now kept.
